markdownRemark.html:
The Beginning In his very first verse Mark offers an astonishing claim: That his book is the beginning of the Good News about Jesus.

Yet, a Western reader could easily be forgiven for wondering how Mark’s collection of stories reflects good news for us to accept, adopt, and apply today.

  • How do we accept it–beyond understanding it as a collection of stories for learning moral principles?
  • How do we adopt its teaching–when much of the time there is little overt teaching?
  • How does it inform us in such a compelling way that the only reasonable response is to apply it to our own lives each day?

Principles for understanding Mark’s teaching It is unusual today to teach simply by telling stories without adding extra comments about what the teacher expects his or her student to understand. To understand Mark, I believe it is important to keep the following principles in mind:

  1. Mark teaches primarily by example.
  2. Mark wants us to read ourselves into the stories and to apply them to the extent that they fit in our own lives.

Here is how this works. Fundamentally, I believe that Mark’s book has two points and asks two questions:

  • Will you be baptized–not just ceremonially, but in your heart also, as described in chapter 1.
  • Who is Jesus? What will you do with your understanding of Jesus? If you could be among Jesus’s listeners, with which group would you honestly identify the most? What kinds of things does Jesus say to the people you identify with the most? Is Jesus right? Do you like what this implies about you?

Ultimately: What will you change as–by seeing Jesus through Mark’s eyes–you get to know Jesus more and more yourself?
